author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Maloney vs. Nadler? New York Must Pick a Side (East or West)
description: New congressional lines have put two stalwart Manhattan Democrats on a collision course in the Aug. 23 primary. Barney Greengrass is staying neutral.
content: As he sat in the shade of Riverside Park on a sparkling recent weekday morning in Manhattan, Representative Jerrold Nadler tried to make sense of how two powerful allies suddenly found themselves at war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Rock ’n’ Roll Swindles, Revisited
description: “Pistol,” about the Sex Pistols, and “Angelyne,” about a sex icon, find the reality in pop-culture fakery.
content: For a movement dedicated to shocking the masses and jabbing a safety pin into social pretensions, punk also had a moral streak. It saw itself as a pure corrective to bloated, baroque rock music and posh, remote rock stars. In “Pistol,” Danny Boyle’s rock-bio of the Sex Pistols, John Lydon (Anson Boon), a.k.a. Johnny Rotten, claims that his group is “the most honest band to have ever existed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: At the Spoleto Festival, Opera Is an Act of Liberation
description: Three productions, including the premiere of Rhiannon Giddens and Michael Abels’s “Omar,” distort time in approachable yet provocative ways.
content: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Wander the streets of this Southern city, and you might notice a warping of time and place: a Porsche parked in the driveway of a fastidiously preserved antebellum mansion; a memorial to the American Revolution neighboring one to the secession that spurred the Civil War; a horse-drawn carriage taking tourists past cobblestone streets on their way back to a Carnival cruise ship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: $2 Million Tabernacle Is Stolen From a Brooklyn Church, Police Say
description: Someone apparently armed with a power saw broke into the church and walked off with the solid-gold, bejeweled tabernacle, the police said.
content: When Father Frank Tumino entered the sanctuary at St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn on Saturday for the start of what was supposed to be a beautiful holiday weekend, the cathedral’s sacred space was missing something special — worth $2 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: Calling In Sick Is More Fraught Than Ever
description: A new normal around staying home while sick is impossible in America.
content: On a recent Thursday, my wife and daughter tested positive for the coronavirus (despite my wife’s getting a negative test the day before). I felt fine, but I stayed home from work and spent the weekend in the house tending to my isolating family members. By early Sunday morning, my throat felt sore. I tested negative, but stayed home from work on Monday even though I tested negative again that day. On Tuesday, I was positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Maria Varenikova
title: A Russian Plane Crashed Into a House. Death Was Parceled Out Randomly.
description: Some fortuitous timing in doing chores saved a family that lived in the Ukrainian city of Chernihiv. A few blocks away, things turned out very differently.
content: CHERNIHIV, Ukraine — It was Yulia Hrebnyeva’s fastidiousness that saved the lives of her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Berlinger
title: Vintage Lovers With a Dollar and a Dream
description: For years, dedicated shoppers have spent their Sundays searching for second-hand goods at Jet Rag’s $1 sale.
content: Like clockwork, every Sunday morning at 10:45 a.m. in a parking lot on La Brea Avenue in Los Angeles, the chaos begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and James Hill
title: Of Red Clay and French Existentialism
description: The red clay of Roland Garros is the biggest star of the French Open. So why isn’t there more of it in France, and more French Open champions from the country?
content: PARIS — The most prominent feature of the French Open is that this Grand Slam tournament takes place on the rusty red clay of Roland Garros, a beloved feature that is as much a part of local culture and tradition as the bouquinistes that sell art and used books along the Seine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Karan Deep Singh
title: All 22 Bodies Are Recovered in Nepal Plane Crash
description: The plane went down in bad weather on Sunday while carrying passengers to Jomsom, a tourist destination popular with trekkers.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Rescue workers recovered 22 bodies on Monday and Tuesday after a nearly 48-hour operation to reach and assess the site of a plane crash in the rocky heights of the Himalayas, according to officials in Nepal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: As Ukraine Fights, Does the E.U. Owe It Membership?
description: Brussels supports Kyiv’s battle against Russia, but gaining full membership to the bloc could take years. Is there another way to bind Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia to Europe?
content: BRUSSELS — With Ukraine defending European values and security against a blatant Russian invasion, what obligation does the European Union and NATO have toward Ukraine?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Neil MacFarquhar
title: An explosion in the Russian-occupied city of Melitopol appears to target a pro-Kremlin leader.
description: Pro-Kremlin authorities in the city blamed Ukrainian partisans for the blast, which they said had injured two people.
content: An explosion rocked the Russian-occupied city of Melitopol early on Monday, sending plumes of smoke into the sky just outside the office of the pro-Kremlin head of the region, according to Ukrainian and Russian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy and Christine Chung
title: Holiday weekend in the U.S. resembles prepandemic times, as experts and the White House remain wary of virus risk.
description: While there is a rise in confirmed daily coronavirus cases and hospitalizations, Memorial Day observations are not being scrapped.
content: Memorial Day has long been understood as the unofficial start of the U.S. summer, but during the pandemic, it has also come with canceled events, bans on large gatherings and news of lagging vaccination rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A new front in Russia’s war in Ukraine.
content: Ukrainian soldiers launched a counteroffensive yesterday in Kherson, the key city that Russia has used as a staging ground for operations across southern Ukraine. Ukrainian forces attempted to hold off Russia’s efforts to conquer and cut off a strategic strip of eastern Ukraine. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randy Kennedy
title: Christopher Wool on What Brought a ‘Sunday Painter’ Back to Life
description: “I had been on the treadmill for so long. And then suddenly I felt like I could just be an artist again,” he says. His long obsession with photo books has now taken full flight.
content: When the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum organized a retrospective of the paintings and photographs of Christopher Wool in 2013, the artist was to be found some months beforehand not making new work or poring over exhibition models. Instead, he had decamped from New York entirely to live near a small printer in Verona, Italy, spending 12 hours a day on press for two weeks to ensure that the book for the show achieved the precise feel that he wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Juston Jones
title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
description: A day after fighting in Ukraine expanded on another front, with the military announcing a counteroffensive around the southern port city of Kherson, European leaders will be gathering in Brussels for a two-day summit focused on the war in Ukraine.
content: A day after fighting in Ukraine expanded on another front, with the military announcing a counteroffensive around the southern port city of Kherson, European leaders will be gathering in Brussels for a two-day summit focused on the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Cilic Delivers Latest French Open Surprise, Beating Medvedev
description: The veteran Marin Cilic dispatched the second-seeded Daniil Medvedev in less than two hours, joining the quarterfinals after Holger Rune upset the fourth-seeded Stefanos Tsitsipas.
content: PARIS — Two days after being encouraged by his clay-court game — and with good reason — Daniil Medvedev, the world’s No. 2 men’s singles player, was bounced out of the French Open on Monday in just 1 hour 45 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Russian Speakers Decide to Use Ukrainian Instead
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 30, 2022.
content: “From the moment we got here, my children and I agreed: We will only speak Ukrainian. I even try to use Ukrainian now in my head — for my inner dialogues.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon
title: Lawyer Who Plotted to Overturn Trump Loss Recruits Election Deniers to Watch Over the Vote
description: A central figure in the scheme to reverse the 2020 election is mobilizing grass-roots activists into an “army of citizens” trained to aggressively monitor elections.
content: In a hotel conference center outside Harrisburg, Pa., Cleta Mitchell, one of the key figures in a failed scheme to overturn Donald J. Trump’s defeat, was leading a seminar on “election integrity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
title: Hit Hard by High Energy Costs, Hawaii Looks to the Sun
description: The state is seeking to replace coal and oil with solar energy, aiming to rely extensively on rooftop panels on single-family homes.
content: HONOLULU — Toddi Nakagawa, who lives in a suburb of Honolulu, has spent years battling her family’s high electricity bills, which once topped $500 a month, by gradually buying more solar panels. After accumulating more than 70 panels and three stacks of batteries, she has gotten her family’s monthly bill down to just $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Carlotta Gall
title: A French journalist is killed by shrapnel in eastern Ukraine.
description: “The newsroom is in mourning,” said a manager at the TV channel where the 32-year-old journalist worked.
content: A 32-year-old French journalist was killed on Monday in eastern Ukraine when the armored bus he was riding in was hit by shrapnel from a shell, according to French and Ukrainian authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Karabell
title: Russia or China? The U.S. Has a Choice to Make.
description: Biden’s administration is wrong to label China as our main strategic threat.
content: In a speech on Thursday, Secretary of State Antony Blinken revealed the long-awaited outlines of the Biden administration’s official posture toward China. Rather than Vladimir Putin’s Russia, Mr. Blinken said, it is China that represents the most potent and determined threat to the American-championed world order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: At Dublin Airport, Staff Shortages Lead to Travel Chaos
description: More than 1,000 passengers missed flights there in a day, part of a spate of similar difficulties across Europe as demand for travel surges.
content: Thousands of travelers waiting outside the terminal. Hourslong lines to pass through security. Calls from frustrated airlines for the army to step in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: N.Y.C. Companies Are Opening Offices Where Their Workers Live: Brooklyn
description: As workers return to the office, some companies have relocated to ease the commute.
content: Before the pandemic, Maz Karimian’s commute to Lower Manhattan was like that of many New Yorkers’: an often miserable 30-minute journey on two subway lines that were usually crammed or delayed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Agatha Moves Across Southern Mexico as a Tropical Storm
description: The storm, which made landfall as Category 2 hurricane, was expected to move inland over the state of Oaxaca on Tuesday before dissipating.
content: Agatha, the year’s first named storm in the eastern Pacific region, was moving across southern Mexico early Tuesday as a tropical storm, hours after making landfall as a Category 2 hurricane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Europe Nears an Oil Embargo
description: The bloc is poised to block the vast majority of Russia’s oil imports.
content: The bloc is poised to agree on a sweeping oil embargo, its most far-reaching effort to punish Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine. The embargo would deprive the Kremlin of a key revenue stream and accelerate Europe’s independence from Russian fuel. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Augustin, Morgan Campbell and Todd Heisler
title: Cuba Steps From Amateur Glory Into the Prize Fighting Chase
description: A move to allow boxers to fight professionally is a big shift for Cuba’s communist government.
content: HAVANA — Fernando Galván charged forward and threw a looping right uppercut. Arlen López, the Cuban boxer who won the light-heavyweight gold medal at the Olympics last summer, took a half-step back and countered with a quick, clinical left hook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Kingsbury
title: No One Can Hide From This Weapon in the War in Ukraine
description: In Ukraine, drones that film and fight have been used to bring international audiences right up to the front lines.
content: All wars have their iconic weapons, from the AK-47 to the I.E.D. In Ukraine, it’s the drone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root and Dana Rubinstein
title: Gov. Hochul Stockpiles Donations, as Rivals Struggle to Keep Pace
description: Real estate, unions and crypto interests were among the donors to Ms. Hochul. Here are five takeaways from the money battle in New York’s race for governor.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — In the final stretch of the primary race for New York governor, the incumbent, Kathy Hochul, has widened her already formidable fund-raising lead over both Democratic and Republican rivals, scooping up millions from lobbyists, wealthy New Yorkers and special interest groups with a stake in policy outcomes in Albany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: The Start of Summer
description: We’ve got some recommendations.
content: This holiday weekend is the unofficial start of summer, and we’re turning today’s newsletter into a summer preview. We’ll cover food, travel, books, sports and movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A two-bedroom condominium unit in Santa Barbara, a 1937 Art Deco house in San Francisco and a 1994 retreat in San Juan Capistrano.
content: This apartment is at the back of a four-unit complex, insulating it from the hustle and bustle of the street. It is in a relatively quiet part of downtown Santa Barbara, with upscale restaurants and shopping. The public library, the Santa Barbara Museum of Art and Alameda Park, which has a playground and a small botanical garden, are a few blocks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombia’s Trump May Be Headed for the Presidential Palace
description: The Colombian establishment is lining up behind Rodolfo Hernández, a populist businessman with an incendiary streak, to defeat the leftist former rebel Gustavo Petro.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Colombia’s political landscape has shifted remarkably in a matter of 24 hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Maria Cramer
title: Man Throws Pastry at Mona Lisa, Smearing Cream on Glass Case
description: The painting was not harmed and the man, who officials said was in a wheelchair and had faked a disability to get close to it, was taken into custody.
content: Luke Sundberg and three of his friends were in line inside the Louvre in Paris on Sunday, waiting to pose for a photo in front of the Mona Lisa, when they heard gasps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: The E.U.’s embargo will bruise Russia’s oil industry, but for now it is doing fine.
description: The European Union reached an agreement to ban most Russian oil imports, which may cause Russian production to drop about 10 percent, analysts say.
content: The European Union’s embargo on Russian oil will bite into the country’s export of crude — a cornerstone of the nation’s economy — but it may not do much damage until the restrictions actually kick in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Military, Where Sexual Misconduct Went to the Top, Looks for a New Path
description: A report by a former Supreme Court justice released Monday offers recommendations to turn around pervasive sexual assault and harassment.
content: OTTAWA — Several of Canada’s top military officers have been accused of sexual harassment, and the former top commander pleaded guilty this year to criminal charges related to accusations that he committed sexual misconduct when leading the nation’s armed forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Nadal and Djokovic Meet Again, With Gen Z Breakout in Wings
description: Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic will play in a quarterfinal at the French Open on Tuesday night, their 59th career meeting and 10th at Roland Garros.
content: PARIS — The rivalry between Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic began in the quarterfinals of the French Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A Church, a Gathering Place for Generations, Becomes a Hub for Uvalde’s Grief
description: As soon as the scale of the tragedy became clear, congregants rushed to Sacred Heart Catholic Church. In the days since, they’ve kept coming in search of comfort and community.
content: UVALDE, Texas — As word of the staggering death toll spread through Uvalde on Tuesday, the parishioners of Sacred Heart Catholic Church rushed, almost reflexively, to be together. Within an hour, they had filled the sanctuary for an impromptu Mass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: How Illinois Is Winning in the Fight Against Big Tech
description: In the absence of federal privacy legislation, the state’s law is considered among the nation’s strongest.
content: The facial recognition company Clearview AI agreed in a settlement this month to stop selling its massive database of photographs culled from the internet to private firms across the United States. That decision is a direct result of a lawsuit in Illinois, a demonstration that strong privacy laws in a single state can have nationwide ramifications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Steven Erlanger
title: For NATO, Turkey Is a Disruptive Ally
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s block on NATO membership for Sweden and Finland is likely to be managed, but Washington and the rest of the alliance are annoyed.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey threatened this month to block NATO membership for Finland and Sweden, Western officials were exasperated — but not shocked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Mohn
title: How the ‘Queen of Slag’ Is Transforming Industrial Sites
description: The landscape architect Julie Bargmann focuses on contaminated and forgotten urban sites. The results are both beautiful and socially conscious.
content: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Trash Is His Muse: Meet the Sanitation Department’s Resident Artist
description: Sto Len focuses much of his work on environmental issues in New York City, including sites like the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.
content: At first glance, Sto Len looks fresh off a New York City garbage truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Scott Cacciola
title: Boston Celtics Beat Miami Heat in Game 7 for Trip to N.B.A. Finals
description: The Celtics led by 15 after the first quarter. Miami’s Jimmy Butler fueled the Heat’s comeback attempt, but it wasn’t enough.
content: MIAMI — For the Boston Celtics, winning the Eastern Conference finals is nothing new. Making it to the N.B.A. finals, which the franchise has now done 22 times, is nothing to celebrate much. The Celtics don’t hang those banners, they like to say. There isn’t room among the 17 in the rafters for winning N.B.A. championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By An Rong Xu and Leslie Nguyen-Okwu
title: Asian and Black Communities Have a Long History of Shared Solidarity
description: Stories of loss, struggle, change and hope are the most powerful tools we have to understand one another and bridge what divides us.
content: Black and Asian communities in America today are often portrayed as in conflict with each other. But we have a long history of organizing with each other, too. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, Asian Americans working as immigrant laborers in the United States were often subjected to racial violence. That experience of discrimination created solidarity with the Black community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Eurovision Winners Auction Off Trophy to Support Ukraine’s Army
description: Millions of people have viewed a video of the band Kalush Orchestra that was filmed in the rubble of Ukraine. Its members have urged fans to help the Ukrainian army.
content: Ukraine’s victory at the Eurovision Song Contest brought national pride, joy and artistic prestige to the country amid the devastation of war. Now, it will also help supply drones to the Ukrainian army.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Men Lost to 20 Bruckner Boulevard
description: They were transforming a century-old Bronx ice house into a charter school. It became one of the deadliest construction sites in New York City in almost two decades.
content: Two laborers board an elevator at the top of a five-story building under renovation in the Bronx. They wear construction helmets, reflective vests and face masks, none of which will do them any good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schweit
title: I Created the F.B.I.’s Active Shooter Program. The Officers in Uvalde Did Not Follow Their Training.
description: Is training to respond to active shooter attacks working?
content: After watching the tragedy at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, unfold after so many other shootings in recent weeks, I’m wondering what I might have missed when I was asked to start the F.B.I.’s active shooter program 10 years ago. Did I have my team focus on the wrong problems? Did I spend my budget wisely to find ways to save lives?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Julia’ and the MTV Movie & TV Awards
description: A documentary about Julia Child airs on CNN. And Vanessa Hudgens hosts an awards show on MTV.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 30-June 3. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Tariq Panja
title: Under Fire for Chaos at Soccer Final, France Rejects Blame for Failures
description: Tear gas and delays marred the Champions League final in Paris on Saturday, raising questions over France’s ability to host large-scale sporting events like the 2024 Summer Olympics.
content: PARIS — French authorities faced a firestorm of criticism on Monday following the chaotic scenes of confusion and violence at the Champions league final between Real Madrid and Liverpool near Paris over the weekend, tarnishing France’s image as a capable host ahead of major sporting events like the 2024 Summer Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why the Producer of ‘Top Gun: Maverick’ Is Betting Big on Theaters
description: David Ellison on making a “love letter to aviation” and the future of theaters, streaming and A.R./V.R.
content: “Top Gun: Maverick” is expected to be one of the first blockbusters of the summer. But as streaming platforms proliferate and movie theaters continue to struggle, is a movie that was designed to be seen on the biggest screen possible be able to lure audiences back to theaters? David Ellison thinks so. He’s the founder and C.E.O. of Skydance Media, the company behind the film, as well as other action franchise reboots like “Mission: Impossible” and “Terminator.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: From Sandy Hook to Uvalde, the Violent Images Never Seen
description: Frustrated Americans ask whether the release of graphic photos of gun violence would lead to better policy. But which photos, and who decides?
content: WASHINGTON — After Lenny Pozner’s six-year-old son Noah died at Sandy Hook, he briefly contemplated showing the world the damage an AR-15-style rifle did to his child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: In the Senate, Chasing an Ever-Elusive Gun Law Deal
description: After a string of Democratic failures on marquee issues, Senator Chuck Schumer’s decision to give bipartisan gun talks time is a test of the Senate — and of democracy itself.
content: WASHINGTON — The decision of the Senate majority leader, Chuck Schumer of New York, to try for a negotiated compromise on new gun laws in the wake of the latest pair of mass shootings may prove to be a high-stakes bet on representative democracy itself, made at a time when faith in Congress — and the Senate in particular — is in tatters in both parties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: A Son Was Lost, a Daughter Saved
description: In Uvalde, Texas, where many children were killed, one family grieves the death of a small boy and holds his sister close.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Jose Flores and Andrea Herrera, inseparable siblings both in the fourth grade, rode the bus together to Robb Elementary School last Tuesday as they did most mornings. They said their cheerful goodbyes. He headed into Room 111, she into Room 104.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: You May See a New Meteor Shower in Night Skies, or Nothing at All
description: A comet’s breakup three decades ago could produce a seldom-seen meteor storm on Monday night. Or it could be a complete dud.
content: A never-before-seen meteor shower may light up the skies with untold numbers of brilliant streaks the evening of Monday night into Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Canada Plans to Ban Handgun Sales and Possession of Assault Weapons
description: “We have a responsibility to act to prevent more tragedies,” Prime Minister Trudeau said as he proposed tightening the country’s already stringent control of firearms.
content: OTTAWA — Most owners of what Canada calls “military-style assault weapons” would be required to turn over their firearms to a government buyback program under legislation introduced on Monday, which would tighten the country’s already stringent control of firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 30, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 30, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanne Derks
title: Circling Sicily on Its Regional Trains
description: A Dutch photographer, documenting the culture of regional train travel, managed to get around the Italian island for less than $100. Here’s what she saw.
content: I was pacing impatiently in my hotel room on the Via Etnea, one of the main boulevards in the center of Catania. Looking out from my balcony, I wondered if the rain was ever going to stop. I’d arrived here on the eastern coast of Sicily earlier in the day, planning to complete a 2.5-week trip to document the Italian island’s culture of regional train travel, but the weather didn’t look promising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juan A. Ramírez
title: Abba Voyage Review: No Ordinary Abba Night at the Club
description: With a concert spectacle mixing wizardry and technical skill, the band makes a case for its continued relevance.
content: LONDON — I kept turning to my friend, wanting to tell him how young and fresh the two women that put the As in Abba seemed on the giant screens ahead of us. Agnetha Faltskog and Anni-Frid Lyngstad were not actually in the room with us, but that’s the kind of stupor Abba Voyage dazzles you into.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Kenny Moore, Marathoner and Track Writer, Dies at 78
description: A three-time All-American, he began a long career at Sports Illustrated while still competing. A former top editor there said, “He was a guy with a real literary bent.”
content: Kenny Moore, a two-time Olympic marathon runner who used his deep understanding of athletes to become a pre-eminent track writer at Sports Illustrated for nearly 25 years, died on May 4 at his home in Kailua, Hawaii. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: They Served. Now, Inspired by What They Saw, They Sell.
description: Some veterans have started businesses that draw from their experiences in Iraq and Afghanistan, and thrived.
content: Over two decades of war, American service members overseas looked across the rubble, the destroyed fields and the ripped-up homes and saw possibilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: In Colombia, a Leftist and a Right-Wing Populist Head for June Runoff
description: The results in the first round of voting delivered a stunning blow to Colombia’s dominant conservative political class.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Two anti-establishment candidates, Gustavo Petro, a leftist, and Rodolfo Hernández, a right-wing populist, captured the top two spots in Colombia’s presidential election on Sunday, delivering a stunning blow to Colombia’s dominant conservative political class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: U.S. Retakes Top Spot in Supercomputer Race
description: A massive machine in Tennessee has been deemed the world’s speediest. Experts say two supercomputers in China may be faster, but the country didn’t participate in the rankings.
content: The United States has regained a coveted speed crown in computing with a powerful new supercomputer in Tennessee, a milestone for the technology that plays a major role in science, medicine and other fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Watering Cans
description: The best watering cans are not only useful, but nice to look at, too. The real challenge may be choosing just one.
content: You don’t necessarily need a beautiful, ergonomic watering can to keep your potted plants alive. But it doesn’t hurt to have one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Alford
title: The Sneaky, Subversive Thrills of David Sedaris
description: The chronicler of dysfunctional families and oddball enthusiasms returns with a new essay collection, “Happy-Go-Lucky.”
content: In the past five years, David Sedaris has published seven books — two essay collections; an anthology; two diaries, both more than 500 pages long; a visual compendium to the diaries; and an ebook version of an essay. Can an eponymous fragrance be far in the offing? (“Se-daring. For the imp in you.”)
source.name: The New York Times

title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A two-bedroom condominium unit in Santa Barbara, a 1937 Art Deco house in San Francisco and a 1994 retreat in San Juan Capistrano.
content: A two-bedroom condominium unit in Santa Barbara, a 1937 Art Deco house in San Francisco and a 1994 retreat in San Juan Capistrano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: A ham and jam sandwich offers sweet, savory and salty bites, and more ideas for lunch.
content: Good morning. For a bunch of mornings now, I’ve been adding a smear of marmalade to my buttered breakfast bagel and sliced hard-boiled egg, with a sprinkle of kosher salt. I like the hint of sweetness against the egg and salt and bread.
source.name: The New York Times

title: White People Fearful of Being ‘Replaced’
description: Readers discuss a theory being promulgated by Tucker Carlson and others about an organized effort to displace white Americans. Also: Mitch McConnell, Ukraine and Trumpism.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
